RautSoft.math.approximation
Class Approximation

java.lang.Object
  RautSoft.math.approximation.Approximation

public class Approximation
extends java.lang.Object

This class contains various public static methods for Interpolation and Approximation methods. The main methods include

  • polint(): Polynomial interpolation
  • ratint (): Interpolation using rational funcitons also known as Pade Approximation
  • ChebyshevApprox(): Chebyshevinterpolation and regression techniques
  • splint(): cubic spline Approximation
The above methods are also going to be avaiable in future for x as two dimensional vectors.i.e., for funcitons of two vairables. The methods are polint2 ratint2, ChebyshevApprox2 splint2 in future

Since:
1.0
Version:
1.0
Author:
Lakshmi K. Raut

polint

public static double polint(double[] xa,
                            double[] ya,
                            double x,
                            nrutil.pDouble dy)
Give double vectors of xa and ya, it calulates the polynomial of degree n-1, and returns the y-value at a given x and error estimate, where n is the number of points in the vector

Parameters:
xa - a double vactor of x values
ya - a double cector of y values
x - a double value at which the approximated polynomial is to be evaluated
dy - a pDouble giving the error estimate on return
Returns:
the value of the polynomial, a double value

Give double vectors of xa and ya, it calulates the polynomial of degree n-1, and returns the y-value at a given x and error estimate, where n is the number of points in the vector

Parameters:
xa - a double vactor of x values
ya - a double cector of y values
x - a double value at which the approximated polynomial is to be evaluated
dy - A double giving the error estimate, it is not returned
Returns:
the value of the polynomial, a double value

spline

public static double[] spline(double[] x,
                              double[] y,
                              double yp1,
                              double ypn)
Numerical Recipe: Given double arrays x[] and y[] containing a tabulated function, i.e., yi = f(xi), with x1 < x2 < .. . < xN, and given values yp1 and ypn for the first derivative of the interpolating function at points 1 and n, respectively, this routine returns an array y2[] that contains the second derivatives of the interpolating function at the tabulated points xi. If yp1 and/or ypn are equal to 1 × 1030 or larger, the routine is signaled to set the corresponding boundary condition for a natural spline, with zero second derivative on that boundary.

Parameters:
x - a double array of x's
y - a double array of reponses
yp1 - a double specifying derivative at the first point
ypn - a double specifying the derivative at the end point
Returns:
It returns a double vector containing the second order derivative at each point

splint

public static double splint(double[] xa,
                            double[] ya,
                            double yp1,
                            double ypn,
                            double x)
Numerical Recipe: Given the arrays xa[] and ya[], which tabulate a function (with the xai’s in order), and given the array y2a[1..n], which is the output from spline above, and given a value of x, this routine returns a cubic-spline interpolated value y.

Parameters:
yp1 - a double specifying derivative at the first point
ypn - a double specifying the derivative at the end point
xa - a double array of x values
ya - a double array of y values
x - at which the cubic spline approximation is to be evaluated, adouble value
Returns:
the cubic spline value estimate, a double value

ChebyshevApprox

public static double ChebyshevApprox(double[] y,
                                     int m,
                                     double a,
                                     double b,
                                     double x)
Given a vector of y evaluated at the zeroes of the function between rage [a,b] not necessarily [-1,1], and given the order the approxiation n (n should be less than the size of the input vector y) it returns the Chebyschev poynomial approxated value at x. Troubleshooting: O why is there a problem in the sense that I have to reverse the values of a &b in chebev?

chebft

public static double[] chebft(double a,
                              double b,
                              int n,
                              FunctionOfOneVariable func)
Returns the coefficients of the Chebyshev polynomial approximation to a function func defined in the range [a,b]. Numerical Recipe: Chebyshev fit: Given a function func (used from the Interface packagage), lower and upper limits of the interval [a,b], and a maximum degree n, this routine computes and returns the n coefficients c[0..n-1] such that func(x) is approximately equal to chevfit at all the chebyschev zeroes as in equation (5.8.10) of Numerical Recipe. This routine is to be used with moderately large n (e.g., 30 or 50), the array of c's subsequently to be truncated at the smaller value m such that c_m and subsequent elements are negligible.

Parameters:
a - lower limit of the function func, a double
b - upper limit of the function func, a double
n - the degree of the polynomial fit that is sought, an int
func - the function which is to be approximated by a Chebyshev polynomial, specified as a FunctionOfOneVariable type
Returns:
a 1-D array of doubles containing the coefficients of the best fit Chebyshev polynomial

chebev

public static double chebev(double a,
                            double b,
                            double[] c,
                            int m,
                            double x)
Chebyshev evaluation: All arguments are input. c[0..m-1] is an array of Chebyshev coeffi- cients, the first m elements of c output from chebft (which must have been called with the same a and b). The Chebyshev polynomial m-1 k=0 ckTk(y) - c0/2 is evaluated at a point y = [x - (b + a)/2]/[(b - a)/2], and the result is returned as the function value.
